questions.text: Bio-film confer resistance to antibiotics by all except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adherence

 

Adherence is a mechanism of bacteria to attach to host cell for penetration. It is not a mechanism of resistance.

 

Mechanisms of biofilm-mediated resistance to antibiotics:

 

  • Mechanical barrier: The lipopolysaccharide biofilms prevent entry of water-soluble drugs.
  • Efflux pumps: These pumps on the biofilms actively excrete drug out.
  • Slow metabolism: Decreased oxygen and nutrients passage through the biofilms slows down the metabolism of bacteria.
  • Anaerobic pathway: Because of the above reason bacteria follow anaerobic metabolism.
  • Persisters: Some bacteria undergo phenotypic modification into dormant, spore-like structure and survive antibiotic insult. These are called as persisters which are activated later.
  • Enzymatic inactivation of drugs by biofilms
  • Genetic adaptation to antibiotic insults
  • Quorum sensing: It is cell to cell signaling among the bacteria to coordinate among themselves for contribution in biofilm synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical barrier: Correct. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents the entry of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Increased excretion of antibiotics: Correct. Efflux pumps in biofilms actively expel antibiotics, reducing their intracellular concentration.

 

Option C. Slow metabolism: Correct. The slow metabolic rate within biofilms makes bacteria less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer resistance to antibiotics through mechanisms such as mechanical barriers, efflux pumps, slow metabolism, and the presence of persisters. Adherence, while important for colonization, does not contribute directly to antibiotic resistance within biofilms.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

The INSURE technique stands for INtubate, SURfactant, and Extubate. This method is used primarily in the management of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease. The procedure involves:

 

  1. Intubating the newborn to establish a secure airway.
  2. Administering surfactant directly into the lungs to reduce surface tension and improve lung function.
  3. Extubating the newborn after the surfactant has been given to allow for spontaneous breathing with the aid of non-invasive ventilation, if necessary.

 

Hyaline membrane disease occurs in preterm infants due to the immaturity of the lungs and a deficiency of surfactant, a substance that prevents the alveoli in the lungs from collapsing. The INSURE technique is effective in providing the necessary surfactant and reducing the severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This option is incorrect because meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in post-term infants who inhale meconium-stained amniotic fluid, leading to respiratory distress. The INSURE technique is not used for this condition.

 

Option B. Transiente tachypnea of newborn: This option is incorrect because transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limited condition seen in term infants caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. It typically resolves without the need for surfactant administration.

 

Option D. Neonatal jaundice: This option is incorrect because neonatal jaundice, caused by elevated bilirubin levels, is not related to lung function or surfactant deficiency. The INSURE technique is not applicable to this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of total energy requirement

questions.text: Dr. Anil, working as a nutritional consultant with the government of India, is reviewing the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, an initiative to enhance the nutritional intake among school-going children. He emphasizes that the nutritional component of the meals should not just be about filling stomachs but ensuring that children get adequate protein and energy to support their growth and learning. Given the constraints and the need to ensure minimal nutritional adequacy, what should the minimum supplementation be in the Mid-Day Meal to support the children's needs? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) ½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
  • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
  • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
  • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
  • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

  • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • As per Williams Obstetrics:
    • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
    • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
    • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Additional 300kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.

 

Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.

 

Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman living in a rural community with limited access to clean water and sanitation presents with repeated episodes of eye irritation, discharge, and blurred vision. On examination, she has evidence of trichiasis and corneal scarring. The ophthalmologist discusses the SAFE strategy as part of the trachoma prevention plan, including measures that can help prevent further complications. Which of the following is NOT part of the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Vector control

 

Explanation:

 

C) Vector control:

 

Vector control is not a part of the SAFE strategy. While managing vectors is critical in other diseases, such as malaria, the SAFE strategy specifically targets the direct human factors involved in the transmission of trachoma rather than insect control.

 

The SAFE strategy is a well-established approach to combating trachoma, particularly in low-resource settings. It stands for Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, and Environmental change. This comprehensive strategy targets both the treatment of active infection and the prevention of disease transmission through improved hygiene and environmental modifications.

 

A. Surgery (S):

 

Surgery is aimed at correcting trichiasis, a condition where the eyelashes turn inward and rub against the cornea, which can lead to blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea and preserves vision.

 

B. Antibiotics (A):

 

Antibiotics, such as azithromycin, are used to treat the active infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration in endemic areas reduces the bacterial load within the community and controls the spread of infection.

 

Facial Cleanliness (F):

 

Promoting facial hygiene, especially in children, reduces the transmission of trachoma. Regular face washing helps remove infectious discharge, which is a key mode of transmission.

 

D. Environmental Change (E):

 

Environmental improvements focus on enhancing access to clean water, sanitation, and promoting better hygiene practices. This reduces the overall transmission of the infection by minimizing the conditions that foster the spread of trachoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The SAFE strategy, consisting of Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, and Environmental change, is a comprehensive public health approach to prevent trachoma-related blindness. Each component works synergistically to treat existing cases and prevent the spread of this infectious eye disease in at-risk populations.

choices.text: BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rota virus 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

questions.text: As a Medical Officer at a Community Health Center (CHC), you're consulted by a mother about starting immunizations for her 13-month-old son who hasn't received any vaccines since birth. Based on the national immunization schedule, which combination of vaccines would you recommend for this child's initial immunization? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

 

  • DPT-1, OPV-1 and Measles 1st dose will be given to this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

D. Mitochondrial - 1. LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy):

LHON is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA affecting the optic nerve and leading to vision loss.

 

A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) - 2. Myotonic Dystrophy:

Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle wasting and myotonia, caused by an expanded repeat sequence in the DMPK gene.

 

B. AR (Autosomal recessive) 3. Cystic Fibrosis:

Cystic Fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

 

C. XR (X-Linked Recessive) 4. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different genetic disorders are inherited through various modes of inheritance: autosomal dominant (e.g., Myotonic Dystrophy), autosomal recessive (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis), X-linked recessive (e.g., Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy), and mitochondrial (e.g., LHON).

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right occipito-anterior

 

The Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position means the fetal occiput (the back of the head) is directed towards the mother's right side and anterior (towards the front of the pelvis). This position indicates that the fetus is facing towards the mother's right side with its back towards the front of the pelvis.

 

In fetal positions:

 

  • Right occipito-anterior (ROA): The occiput is on the right side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-anterior (LOA): The occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Right occipito-posterior (ROP): The occiput is on the right side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-posterior (LOP): The occiput is on the left side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Right occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the right side but towards the back of the pelvis, not the front.

 

Option B. Left occipito-anterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.

 

Option C. Left occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side but towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position, the fetal occiput is directed towards the mother's right side and the anterior part of the pelvis.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb. The right upper limb is preductal, meaning it receives blood directly from the aorta before it passes through the ductus arteriosus. This positioning is crucial for detecting any discrepancies between preductal and postductal oxygen saturation levels such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation (measured at the foot), it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal left upper limb: Although the left upper limb can be used, the right upper limb is preferred for preductal saturation measurement to ensure accuracy in detecting shunts.

 

Option B. Fetal left lower limb: The left lower limb is postductal, making it unsuitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Option D. Fetal right lower limb: The right lower limb is also postductal and not suitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To measure preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, place the pulse oximeter on the right upper limb. This helps in detecting any right-to-left shunt, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson’s disease

 

The most probable diagnosis for this patient, based on the clinical presentation and the image showing icterus in the eyes, is Wilson's disease. Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which leads to abnormal copper metabolism. This results in copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, cornea, and kidneys.

 

The presence of intentional tremors, poor scholastic performance, and hepatomegaly are consistent with Wilson's disease. The eye finding likely represents a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, a characteristic feature of Wilson's disease. The KF ring is a brownish or golden ring around the cornea, which is caused by copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington's chorea: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements (chorea), cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances. Unlike Wilson's disease, Huntington's chorea does not typically present with hepatomegaly or KF rings.

 

Option C. Glutaric aciduria: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder that usually presents in the first 6 months of life. Clinical features include hypotonia, jitteriness, and progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis). This disorder does not present with the eye findings seen in the image or the liver involvement typical of Wilson's disease.

 

Option D. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is a viral infection transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route. It typically presents with symptoms such as jaundice, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. However, it does not cause the neurological symptoms, intentional tremors, or KF rings seen in Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease is characterized by the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly, neurological symptoms (such as intentional tremors), and is diagnosed with decreased serum ceruloplasmin, increased 24-hour urinary copper excretion, and the presence of KF rings.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine Sulfate eye ointment

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is utilized in the management of fungal corneal ulcers primarily to relieve symptoms like pain due to ciliary spasm and to prevent complications such as the formation of posterior synechiae. Atropine achieves this by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscles, thus providing a therapeutic benefit in the treatment of corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine e/d: Generally used to contract the pupil in glaucoma treatment, not appropriate for corneal ulcers as it can increase pain by causing ciliary spasm.

 

Option B. Lignocaine e/d: An anesthetic used for temporary pain relief but does not serve as adjuvant therapy in managing ulcers.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone e/d: A corticosteroid, generally avoided in fungal infections due to its potential to exacerbate infections by suppressing immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to relieve pain and prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscle.

choices.text: Rocky mountain spotted fever

questions.text: Which disease causes the lesion shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

The lesion shown in the image is eschar. It is seen in scrub typhus.

 

Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the rickettsial bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

It is transmitted to humans by the bite of the larva of trombiculid mites. Later it causes disseminated vasculitis and perivascular inflammation ultimately leading to significant vascular leakage leading to end-organ injury.

 

Clinical features usually arise after an incubation period of 6-21 days and manifest as fever, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. An eschar which usually begins as a primary papular lesion later crusts to form a black ulcer with central necrosis is a distinct feature of scrub typhus although its presence varies in different regions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: A classic case of Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) involves a rash that appears 2-4 days after the onset of fever as small, flat, pink, macules on the wrists, forearms, and ankles and spreads to include the trunk and sometimes the palms of hands and soles of feet.

 

Option B: Malaria is a protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium species characterized by periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option D: COVID-19 is a highly contagious viral disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

 

Educational Objective

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by an eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with fever and systemic symptoms.

choices.text: IV fluids and furosemide
Chemotherapy with gemcitabine and carboplatin

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with lung carcinoma presents with a serum calcium level of 16.4 mmol/L. What should be the initial step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A. IV fluids and furosemide

 

Explanation:

 

The initial therapy for significant hypercalcemia involves volume expansion because hypercalcemia invariably leads to dehydration. Administering 4-6 liters of intravenous saline over the first 24 hours is essential, especially considering underlying comorbidities such as congestive heart failure, which may necessitate the use of loop diuretics like furosemide to enhance sodium and calcium excretion. It is crucial to restore the patient's volume status before initiating loop diuretics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Immediate hemodialysis: Hemodialysis is not typically the first-line treatment for hypercalcemia. It is reserved for severe cases where there is renal failure, life-threatening hypercalcemia, or when other measures fail.

 

Option C. Bisphosphonates: While bisphosphonates are effective in treating hypercalcemia of malignancy, they are not the initial treatment. They are usually administered after volume expansion and stabilization of the patient.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy with gemcitabine and carboplatin: Chemotherapy is not an immediate treatment for hypercalcemia. While treating the underlying malignancy is important, the initial management of hypercalcemia focuses on correcting the electrolyte imbalance.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The initial management of significant hypercalcemia, particularly in patients with malignancy, involves aggressive hydration with intravenous saline to address dehydration and potentially the use of loop diuretics to enhance calcium excretion

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2

 

The third part of the vertebral artery (V3) is related to the area marked 2, which is the posterior arch of the first cervical vertebra or the atlas.

 

The given image shows the first cervical vertebra - atlas.

 

  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the of vertebral artery and venous plexus immediately behind.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.
  • The area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch. It gives attachment to the apex of dens from the second cervical vertebra.

 

The vertebral artery is formed by the first segment of the subclavian artery. It enters the cranium through the foramina of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae from C6 to C1. The basilar artery is formed by the union of the vertebral arteries on both sides. In its course. it is divided into four parts:

 

  1. The first part, V1: begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side.
  2. The second part, V2: is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae.
  3. The third part, V3: is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle.
  4. The fourth part, V4: pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

questions.text: The attachment of Eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Guanyl cap

 

In eukaryotic cells, the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is facilitated by the presence of a 5' cap structure, specifically an N7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap, also known as the guanyl cap. This cap is essential for several functions, including the initiation of translation.

 

Functions of the Guanyl Cap:

 

  1. Initiation of Translation: The 5' cap is recognized by the eukaryotic initiation factors (eIFs), particularly eIF4E, which is a part of the eIF4F complex. This recognition is crucial for the recruitment of the ribosome to the mRNA.
  2. Protection: The cap structure protects the mRNA from degradation by 5' to 3' exonucleases.
  3. Splicing and Export: The cap structure also plays roles in pre-mRNA splicing, polyadenylation, and the export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poly A tail: The polyadenylation (poly A tail) at the 3' end of mRNA enhances stability and facilitates the export of mRNA from the nucleus. It also aids in the regulation of translation but does not directly mediate ribosome attachment.

 

Option B. tRNA: Transfer RNA (tRNA) is involved in the translation process by bringing amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis, but it does not mediate the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome.

 

Option D. Shine-Dalgarno Sequence: The Shine-Dalgarno sequence is a ribosomal binding site found in prokaryotic mRNA. It helps in the alignment of the ribosome with the start codon, but it is not present in eukaryotic mRNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The attachment of eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the 5' guanyl cap, which plays a crucial role in the initiation of translation, protection of mRNA, and its processing and export from the nucleus.

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 10%

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A patient with HIV develops diarrhea and faecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with cotrimoxazole. Diarrhoea subsided but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image below. Which of the following statement is false? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

Based on the clinical picture, an HIV positive patient had infection with Isospora belli which was treated with cotrimoxazole. The bone marrow examination showed narrow based budding yeast cells suggestive of infection with Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus which exists as a mycelial form at ambient temperatures and grows as small round budding yeast cells at body temperature in mammals.
  • Growth on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25ºC shows a white to brown colony, cottony mycelium after 2 to 3 weeks.
  • The mold phase is characterized by thin, branching, septate hyphae that produce microconidia and a very distinct spore called a tuberculate macroconidium.
  • Grown at 37ºC shows the budding yeast form. Yeast cells occur within budding yeasts as intracellular fungi.
  • The yeast cell is 2-4 µm in diameter and slightly oval in shape and found exclusively within macrophages.
  • Mode of infection - Inhalation of spores
  • Disseminated infection can occur in immunocompromised patients with reticuloendothelial system being affected the most.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: Correct. Spores of Histoplasma capsulatum are the infective form. They are inhaled into the lungs, where they convert to yeast form and cause infection.

 

Option C. It is intracellular budding yeast: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular budding yeast when it infects the host. It is typically found within macrophages.

 

Option D. It can cause systemic disease: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause systemic disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, a thermally dimorphic fungus, can grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar, produce infective spores, exist as an intracellular budding yeast in humans, and cause systemic disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a hysteroscopic removal of a submucosal fibroid, in which a fluid deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario depicts case of fluid overload, due to which pulmonary edema can develop.

 

  • During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels.
  • Fluid deficit can be estimated by manual calculation or by use of an automated fluid management system.
  • When using hypotonic solutions (like glycine), the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000mL for healthy patients and 750mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • For normal saline, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2,500mL for healthy patients and 750mL for those with cardiovascular disease.
  • If excessive absorption of fluid occurs with a hypotonic fluid; obtain serum electrolytes and the patient should be evaluated for volume overload.
  • Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output.
  • Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and managed in intensive care.
  • Fluid overload from normal saline can be managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis: While fluid overload can contribute to kidney injury, acute tubular necrosis is not the immediate complication in this scenario.

 

Option B. DIC: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a serious condition involving abnormal blood clotting but is not directly related to fluid overload from hysteroscopy.

 

Option D. Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism involves blood clots traveling to various parts of the body but is not the immediate consequence of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid overload during hysteroscopic surgery can lead to pulmonary edema as an immediate complication due to excessive absorption of uterine distension fluid.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a feature of delayed blood transfusion reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Increased unconjugated bilirubin
  2. Cola colored urine after 2 hours
  3. Increased LDH
  4. Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 4

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions typically occur more than 24 hours after the initiation of a blood transfusion. These reactions can result from various immune-mediated processes, often involving the destruction of transfused red blood cells. The features of delayed blood transfusion reactions include:

 

  • Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This occurs due to hemolysis, where the breakdown of red blood cells releases hemoglobin that is converted into unconjugated bilirubin.
  • Increased LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues, including red blood cells. When red blood cells are destroyed, LDH levels in the blood increase.
  • Failure of rise of hemoglobin after transfusion: Despite the transfusion, the hemoglobin level does not increase as expected because the transfused red blood cells are being destroyed.

 

Incorrect Statement 

 

Statement 2 Cola colored urine after 2 hours: Cola-colored urine shortly after transfusion is indicative of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, not a delayed reaction. Delayed hemolytic reactions typically present with cola-colored urine after several days, not within 2 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed blood transfusion reactions occur more than 24 hours after transfusion and are characterized by increased unconjugated bilirubin, increased LDH, and failure of hemoglobin levels to rise. Immediate cola-colored urine indicates an acute reaction, not a delayed one.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

 

Explanation:

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

 

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.

 

Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is  a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCL 1

 

MCL 1 is an anti-apoptotic gene which prevents apoptosis by binding to and neutralizing pro-apoptotic proteins such as BAX and BAK. MCL1 plays a crucial role in resistance to chemotherapy drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PUMA: PUMA (p53 upregulated modulator of apoptosis) is a pro-apoptotic gene that is activated by p53 and plays a role in promoting apoptosis by inhibiting anti-apoptotic BCL-2 family members.

 

Option B. BAD: BAD is another pro-apoptotic protein that promotes apoptosis by binding to and inhibiting anti-apoptotic proteins such as BCL-2 and BCL-XL.

 

Option C. BAK: BAK is a pro-apoptotic protein that, when activated, oligomerizes and disrupts the mitochondrial membrane, leading to cytochrome c release and the activation of caspases, which are crucial for apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Maddox Rod Test

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with complaints of double vision and misalignment of the eyes, which worsen when looking in specific directions. On examination, the patient exhibits a limitation of eye movement suggestive of a muscle weakness. A chart is used to evaluate the muscle function of both eyes and assess the binocular visual field. The chart reveals a disparity between the movements of both eyes. Based on this description, identify the chart shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Hess Chart

 

Explanation:

 

The Hess chart is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to assess the field of binocular single vision and is commonly used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus. This condition is characterized by a difference in eye movement due to paralytic or mechanical factors, often seen in cases of cranial nerve palsy or restrictive strabismus.

 

Purpose of the Hess Chart:

 

The Hess chart is used to evaluate binocular vision and ocular muscle function, particularly in cases of strabismus where eye movements are not aligned or restricted.

 

How the Hess Chart Works:

 

The chart consists of two grids, one representing each eye's movement. A smaller chart usually indicates the eye with the weaker or paretic muscle, and a larger chart reflects the eye with an overacting muscle compensating for the deficiency.

 

Use in Diagnosing Incomitant Strabismus:

 

Incomitant strabismus involves differences in eye movement based on direction due to mechanical or paralytic causes. The Hess chart helps pinpoint which muscles are underperforming or overcompensating.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

This chart is particularly valuable in managing patients with cranial nerve palsies, orbital fractures, or conditions affecting the extraocular muscles, allowing targeted therapy or surgical planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Goldmann Perimetry: Used for assessing visual fields, not specifically for strabismus or muscle function.

 

Option B) Maddox Rod Test: Used for evaluating phorias and tropias, assessing alignment rather than muscle strength.

 

Option D) Amsler Grid: Designed to detect macular problems, such as in age-related macular degeneration, not used for strabismus or binocular vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is essential for assessing binocular single vision and diagnosing conditions that affect eye alignment and muscle function, particularly incomitant strabismus. Understanding its role helps in the targeted management of patients with complex ocular motility disorders.

questions.text: What is the bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100%

 

Bioavailability of an administered drug is the fraction of that drug that reaches unchanged into systemic circulation. It depends upon 2 factors:

 

  • Absorption of the drug from the site of application
  • First pass metabolism

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously (I.V) is 100% because it is neither subjected to the first-pass metabolism as in oral route nor does it depend on local factors that affect absorption as in subcutaneous, intramuscular, or transdermal. In IV route, the drug is directly delivered to the systemic circulation and hence has the maximum availability for action at the intended site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is 100% because the drug is directly delivered into the systemic circulation without any loss due to absorption barriers or first-pass metabolism.

questions.text: A physician wanted to perform plasma glucose estimation using the vacutainer shown in the image. Which of the following is the anticoagulant used for this test? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium oxalate

 

  • Potassium oxalate is commonly used in vacutainers for plasma glucose estimation because it acts as both an anticoagulant and it prevents clotting by binding calcium in the blood. We presume that the examiner by mistake showed the blue topped vacutainer in place of the gray one. However let us review that blue-topped vacutainer contains Trisodium citrate while the gray-topped vacutainer contains Potassium oxalate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisodium Citrate: Used primarily as an anticoagulant in blood collection tubes for coagulation studies, not suitable for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis effectively.

 

Option C. Sodium fluoride: Also a glycolysis inhibitor and commonly used with an anticoagulant (potassium oxalate) in glucose testing..

 

Option D. EDTA: Mainly used as an anticoagulant in hematology tests. While it effectively prevents blood clots, it does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate plasma glucose estimation, potassium oxalate and enolase is used because it effectively prevents blood clotting and preserves glucose by inhibiting glycolysis respectively. 

 

Always use a grey-top tube (NaF/KOx) when measuring plasma glucose to prevent post-collection glycolysis and falsely low results.

questions.text: Specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS CoV-2 would require? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BSL2

 

Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2) is required for handling specimens for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2. BSL-2 facilities are designed for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes diagnostic and other procedures involving the manipulation of known or suspected infectious materials, such as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19.

 

For culturing SARS-CoV-2, which involves growing the virus, higher containment is necessary. Therefore, BSL-3 facilities would be required to ensure higher levels of protection against aerosol transmission and potential infection.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. BSL1: This level is used for work with well-characterized agents that are not known to consistently cause disease in healthy adults and present minimal potential hazard to laboratory personnel and the environment. It is not suitable for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens.

 

Option C. BSL3: While this level is appropriate for culturing SARS-CoV-2 due to the need for higher containment, it is not required for routine molecular testing.

 

Option D. BSL4: This level is reserved for work with dangerous and exotic agents that pose a high risk of aerosol-transmitted laboratory infections and life-threatening disease. It is not necessary for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens for molecular testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

SARS CoV 2 requires BSL-2 or equivalent facilities.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 months

 

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

 

 

Fig: Bidextrous grasp approach to a dangling ring 4 months

 

Fine motor development:

 

  • Hands come together in midline by 5 months
  • Bidextrous Reach comes by 4 months
  • Tries to reach for object from both hand will be bidextrous approach & from one hand will be unidextrous approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bidextrous reach, where a baby uses both hands to reach out for objects, is typically achieved by 4 months of age.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 700 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it, even though it occurs continually in all living humans. It is about 700 mL/day or 50 mL/hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolactin and growth hormone

 

The hypothalamus exerts inhibitory control on both prolactin and growth hormone:

 

  • Prolactin: Inhibition is mediated by Prolactin-Inhibiting Hormone (PIH), which is dopamine. Dopamine inhibits the secretion of prolactin by lactotropes in the anterior pituitary.
  • Growth Hormone: Inhibition is mediated by Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone (GHIH), also known as somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of growth hormone by somatotropes in the anterior pituitary.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hip Internal Rotation
Hip External Rotation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of left hip pain that worsens with certain movements. During the physical examination, the physician performs several maneuvers to assess the range of motion and provoke symptoms. The examiner positions the patient's hip as shown in the diagram to evaluate the hip joint's integrity and function. Which movement of the hip is being demonstrated by the examiner in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Hip Internal Rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The movement demonstrated in the diagram is hip internal rotation. In this maneuver, the examiner moves the lower leg outward, causing the hip to rotate inward. Internal rotation of the hip is commonly assessed during physical examination to detect intra-articular pathology, such as femoroacetabular impingement, labral tears, or early signs of hip arthritis. Pain or restriction during this movement may indicate underlying joint issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Hip External Rotation: This movement involves rotating the thigh outward away from the body’s midline, the opposite of what is demonstrated in the image.

 

Option C) Hip Abduction: Abduction involves moving the leg away from the body's midline, usually assessed for lateral hip pain or abductor muscle weakness.

 

Option D) Hip Flexion: Flexion involves bringing the thigh toward the chest, not the movement depicted in the diagram, where rotation is primarily being evaluated.

 

Educational Objective:


Hip internal rotation is a critical movement to assess during the physical examination of patients with hip pain. This maneuver helps clinicians identify potential intra-articular pathologies affecting the hip joint, guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

questions.text:
Identify true statements about familial adenomatous polyposis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Autosomal recessive inheritance
  2. If not treated, all cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon.
  3. KRAS mutations cause familial adenomatous polyposis
  4. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a hereditary condition characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, often numbering in the hundreds to thousands. The condition is caused by mutations in the APC gene (chromosome 5q), leading to autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

True Statements:

 

Statement 2: If not treated, all cases of FAP will progress to colorectal adenocarcinoma. This is because the polyps have a high potential to become malignant if not removed or if the patient does not undergo a prophylactic colectomy.

 

Statement 4: FAP is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, which is often used as a marker for the condition, especially in screening family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. This means that a single copy of the mutated APC gene can cause the disease.

 

Statement 3: FAP is primarily caused by mutations in the APC gene, not KRAS. While KRAS mutations are involved in colorectal cancer progression, they are not the cause of FAP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: The Para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

Epiploic foramen is the structure indicated in the provided image. The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

 

 

The caudate lobe is a small lobe of the liver situated on the posterior aspect, between the sulcus for the vena cava on the right and the fissure for the ligamentum venosum on the left. The caudate lobe forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is the first part of the small intestine immediately beyond the stomach. While the duodenum is closely related to the epiploic foramen, specifically the posterior surface of its first part, it does not form the superior border. Instead, it comprises the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the start of the duodenum. The free edge of the lesser omentum contains the bile duct, hepatic artery, and portal vein, forming the anterior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower and middle body into the right atrium of the heart. It is located posteriorly to the epiploic foramen but does not form the superior border. It creates the posterior boundary, similar to the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a key anatomical passage within the abdominal cavity that connects the greater sac to the lesser sac.

 

The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of this foramen.

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly except: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aplastic anemia

 

All the above are associated with massive splenomegaly except aplastic anemia.

 

Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia (a reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) due to the failure of the bone marrow. A key feature of aplastic anemia is the absence of splenomegaly. In fact, the presence of splenomegaly in a patient with pancytopenia often argues against the diagnosis of aplastic anemia.

 

There are several potential causes of splenomegaly:

 

  1. Liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis): Parenchymal liver disease causes increased vascular pressure leading to an increase in spleen size.
  2. Hematologic malignancies (lymphomas, leukemias, myeloproliferative disorders): Neoplastic cells cause infiltration of the spleen leading to splenomegaly.
  3. Venous thrombosis (portal or hepatic vein thrombosis): This leads to an increase in vascular pressure leading to splenomegaly.
  4. Splenic congestion (venous thrombosis, portal hypertension, congestive heart failure).
  5. Cytopenias (Immune thrombocytopenic purpura, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, immune-mediated neutropenia, Felty syndrome): Immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells, white blood cells or platelets lead to functional splenomegaly
  6. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell disease, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  7. Acute or chronic infection (bacterial endocarditis, infectious mononucleosis, HIV, malaria, tuberculosis, histiocytosis, abscess).
  8. Connective tissue diseases (systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Adult-onset Still's disease, and some familial autoinflammatory syndromes).[4][5]
  9. Infiltrative disorders (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, glycogen storage diseases).
  10. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  11. Focal lesions (hemangiomas, abscess, cysts, metastasis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). Splenomegaly is characteristically absent; if it is present, the diagnosis of aplastic anemia should be seriously questioned. Similarly, splenomegaly is also never seen in cases of ITP.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg. 1239, 1173

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endocardial cushions

 

Explanation:

 

The interventricular septum's membranous portion is the indicated structure. It comes from the endocardial cushions.

 

 

  • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions.
    • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
    • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Septum primum: The septum primum is involved in the development of the atrial septum, not the interventricular septum. It forms a temporary structure in the embryonic heart that helps separate the atria.

 

Option C. Left venous valve: The left venous valve is not directly involved in the formation of the interventricular septum. It is a structure found within the embryonic heart that helps direct oxygenated blood from the left atrium into the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus is an embryonic structure that contributes to the formation of the smooth part of the right ventricle. It is not associated with the development of the interventricular septum.

 

 

Cardiac abnormalities, such as ASs, VSDs, and anomalies affecting the major arteries, can be caused by errors in the creation of the endocardial cushion (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arterious, and tetralogy of Fallot).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

 

  1. Atrial septa
  2. Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  3. Atrioventricular canals
  4. Atrioventricular valves

 

The membranous portion of the interventricular septum develops from the endocardial cushions.

choices.text: Antibiotics for all cases
Remdesivir for all children
Routine use of antiviral drugs

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is admitted to the ICU with severe COVID-19, presenting with acute respiratory distress syndrome, SpO₂ <90% on room air, and signs of severe pneumonia. The child exhibits grunting, severe chest retractions, and lethargy. A series of investigations, including chest X-ray, blood tests, and other diagnostic evaluations, confirm the severity of the condition. The medical team is planning the appropriate treatment regimen. Which of the following therapies is recommended as part of the management for a child with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

 

Corticosteroids are an essential component of therapy for children with severe COVID-19, particularly in cases involving acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, or multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). These medications help reduce inflammation and manage severe respiratory symptoms in critically ill patients.

 

Identifying Severe COVID-19 in Children:

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as:

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

SpO₂ <90% on room air

Signs of severe pneumonia

Grunting, severe chest retractions, lethargy, somnolence, or seizures

Septic shock

Multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) or pneumonia with cyanosis

 

Investigations for Severe COVID-19:

 

Chest X-ray: To evaluate lung involvement.

 

Blood Tests: Including CBC with ESR, blood glucose, liver and renal function tests (LFT, RFT), CRP, serum ferritin, and D-dimer to assess inflammation and other complications.

 

CT Chest: Not routinely used for diagnosis but considered if respiratory status does not improve.

 

Treatment Recommendations:

 

Hospitalization in HDU/ICU: Severe cases should be managed in a high-dependency or intensive care unit of a designated COVID-19 hospital.

 

Oxygen Therapy: Immediate oxygen therapy is initiated to maintain target oxygen saturation levels of 94-96%.

 

Fluid and Electrolyte Management: To maintain balance and avoid complications.

 

Anticoagulants: Indicated in high-risk cases with a predisposition to thrombosis.

 

Antimicrobials: Administered if there is strong evidence or suspicion of a superadded bacterial infection.

 

Organ Support: May be required in cases of organ dysfunction, such as renal replacement therapy.

 

Guidelines for Use of Steroids:

 

Steroids are used only in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases.

 

Avoided in the first 3-5 days due to viral shedding at this time.

 

Not indicated in asymptomatic and mild cases.

 

Dexamethasone (0.15 mg/kg, max 6 mg once daily) or Methylprednisolone (0.75 mg/kg, max 30 mg once daily) are recommended.

 

Continued for 5-6 days and then tapered off.

 

Additional Points:

 

Remdesivir: Indicated for hospitalized children with mild to moderate COVID-19, but not a routine therapy for severe cases without specific indications.

 

Other Options

 

Option B) Antibiotics for all cases: Not recommended unless there is evidence of bacterial infection, as antibiotics do not treat viral infections.

 

Option C) Remdesivir for all children: Not routinely used in severe COVID-19; its use depends on specific clinical indications.

 

Option D) Routine use of antiviral drugs: Not standard for severe COVID-19 management in children without specific indications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with severe COVID-19, corticosteroids are used to reduce inflammation and manage severe respiratory symptoms under strict guidelines. Recognizing the appropriate use of corticosteroids, along with comprehensive supportive care, is crucial in managing critically ill pediatric patients with severe COVID-19.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.
