Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: The temperature of a body of a deceased person is found to be 39 degrees Celsius. Which of the following is the most probable reason? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septicaemia

 

Septicaemia, a severe infection where bacteria enter the bloodstream, causes the body to produce a high fever due to excessive bacterial activity. This can result in postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death.

 

Postmortem Caloricity: Usually cooling of the body occurs after death, however in certain exceptional conditions the body temperatures remain increased after death for 2-3 hours. This is called Postmortem Caloricity.

 

It can Occur due to two reasons:

 

1) Body temperature was too high before death

 

  1. When Heat regulation is disturbed before death: Heat Stroke, pontine hemorrhage    
  2. Increased heat production due to convulsions: Strychnine poisoning and tetanus
  3. Increased heat production due to excessive bacterial activity: Infectious diseases (Septicaemia, typhoid etc.)

 

2) Very high environmental temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide poisoning leads to rapid death by inhibiting cellular respiration, but it does not typically cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Option C. Corrosive poisoning: Corrosive poisons cause tissue damage and may lead to symptoms such as pain and vomiting, but they do not typically result in postmortem caloricity.

 

Option D. Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: Intra-abdominal hemorrhage involves bleeding within the abdominal cavity, which does not cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death, can occur due to high body temperature before death, such as in cases of septicaemia, heat stroke, and certain poisonings, or due to very high environmental temperature.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 81

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaints of umbilical discharge. Abdominal examination was otherwise normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG Abdomen

 

The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly with an apparent discharging sinus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a safe and non-invasive imaging technique commonly used to evaluate abdominal conditions in pediatric patients. It is particularly useful for assessing the umbilical region and identifying any abnormalities that may be causing the umbilical discharge. USG provides real-time imaging and can help in diagnosing conditions such as umbilical granulomas, urachal abnormalities, or other underlying issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI Abdomen: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) of the abdomen is a valuable diagnostic tool for various abdominal conditions. However, in the case of a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge, an ultrasound (USG) is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. MRI is generally reserved for more complex or specific cases.

 

Option C. СЕСТ: CECT may be done after USG if further information was desired.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: Performing an exploratory laparotomy as the initial step in a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge and an otherwise normal abdominal examination would be overly aggressive and not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

 

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities according to the part of the duct that is persistent.
  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel's diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical sinus, likely to be the case here.
  • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive thoughts that, he always feels his hands are dirty, though they are not. This gives him discomfort and hence he has to wash them again and again. This is a disorder of thought:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Possession

 

The patient is experiencing obsessive thoughts. Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts that cause significant anxiety or distress. The individual recognizes that the obsessions are a product of his or her own mind, but they feel as though they can't control the thoughts, hence they fall under the category of disorders of thought possession.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Flow: Refers to the rate and speed of thoughts. Examples of disorders of flow include flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking.

 

Option B. Form: Refers to the organization and structure of thought. Examples of disorders of form include tangentiality, circumstantiality, and word salad.

 

Option D. Content: Refers to what person is actually thinking about, such as delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obsessions, as seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder, are considered disturbances of thought possession because while the individual recognizes the thoughts as their own, they feel as though they can't control them.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 46.

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levofloxacin

 

Levofloxacin is known for its high bioavailability, approximately 99-100% when administered orally. This means almost all of the administered dose reaches systemic circulation, making it effective for treating a variety of infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin also has good bioavailability, but it is generally lower than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from approximately 70-80%. It is drug of choice for meningococcal meningitis, also effective in enteric fever and anthrax.

 

Option C. Gatifloxacin: The bioavailability of Gatifloxacin varies, but it is generally less than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from around 60-90%. It is a respiratory FQ that causes dysglycemia, therefore has been withdrawn from India.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin has a bioavailability of about 30-40%, which is significantly lower than Levofloxacin. It is mostly used for urinary tract infections because of its lower systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levofloxacin has the highest bioavailability among the listed fluoroquinolones, with nearly 100% of the administered dose reaching systemic circulation. This high bioavailability makes levofloxacin highly effective for a wide range of bacterial infections.

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was admitted complains of dyspnea. On examination he has puffy face, with engorged veins over the chest. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT thorax

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction, suggested by symptoms like dyspnea, facial puffiness, and engorged chest veins, along with a chest X-ray showing mediastinal enlargement, requires further detailed imaging to accurately assess the extent of the obstruction and the presence of any mediastinal masses. A CT scan of the thorax is the most appropriate next step as it provides detailed images of the chest's anatomy, helping to identify the cause of the SVC obstruction, which is crucial for planning appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total blood count with peripheral smear: While useful for general health assessments and diagnosing blood disorders, this does not directly address the structural issues seen in SVC obstruction.

 

Option C. Start cyclophosphamide: Beginning chemotherapy like cyclophosphamide would only be appropriate after a specific diagnosis of a malignancy causing the SVC obstruction, confirmed via imaging and biopsy.

 

Option D. Urgent referral to RT: Referral for radiation therapy (RT) may be necessary if a malignancy is confirmed, but it is premature without a detailed thoracic CT and biopsy if indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT thorax is critical for detailed evaluation in suspected SVC obstruction to confirm the diagnosis and guide further specific treatment, whether surgical, medical, or radiation therapy.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of fatigue. Serum investigations revealed findings as given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hemoglobin – 9 g/dl

 

Mean cell volume (MCV) – 60 fL

 

Mean cell Hb (MCH) – 20 pg

 

Serum Ferritin – 185 mcg/L

 

Total leukocyte count – Elevated lymphocyte and Neutrophils

 

[Reference normal values for this question: Serum Ferritin: 50-200 mcg/L; Mean cell volume (MCV) - 80-100 fL; Mean cell Hb (MCH) - 27-31 pg]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thalassemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, along with laboratory findings, strongly suggests thalassemia.

 

  • MCV of 60 fL and MCH of 20 pg are both very low, indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is typical in thalassemia.
  • Serum ferritin is within the normal range (185 mcg/L), which rules out iron-deficiency anemia, as that condition would typically present with low ferritin levels.
  • The elevated lymphocyte and neutrophil counts could be a secondary response but are not specific to thalassemia.

 

Thalassemia is characterized by a reduction in the synthesis of globin chains (alpha or beta), leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia. The microcytosis and hypochromia (low MCV and MCH) are hallmarks of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disorder: Typically presents with normal to reduced MCV and low serum iron, but ferritin is usually raised, not within the normal range.

 

Option C. Iron-deficiency anemia: Would show low serum ferritin, low MCV, and low MCH, but the serum ferritin here is normal.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: Would not typically present with low MCV and MCH, as sickle cells tend to be normocytic or macrocytic.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with persistently elevated blood pressure readings despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. His current regimen includes an ACE inhibitor, a calcium channel blocker, and a beta-blocker. Despite these medications, his blood pressure remains above target. For a diagnosis of resistant hypertension, which class of drug must be included in his regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target of 140/90 mmHg despite the use of three or more antihypertensive medications of different classes, one of which must be a diuretic. Diuretics are crucial in the management of resistant hypertension because they help reduce fluid retention, which is often a contributing factor in uncontrolled blood pressure.

 

Common Causes of Diuretic Resistance:

 

  • Pseudoresistance: Includes factors like the white coat effect and improper blood pressure measurement techniques.
  • Non-adherence to therapy: Patients not taking medications as prescribed can significantly impact blood pressure control.
  • Improper dosing or irrational combination: Inadequate dosing or ineffective combinations of antihypertensive drugs.
  • Therapeutic inertia: Healthcare providers' failure to adjust treatment appropriately.
  • Secondary causes: Includes conditions such as renal artery stenosis, primary aldosteronism, or obstructive sleep apnea.

 

Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) is recommended for patients with suspected resistant hypertension to rule out pseudoresistance and assess true blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-blocker: Alpha-blockers can be used as an add-on therapy in resistant hypertension but are not mandatory for diagnosis.

 

Option B. Angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB): While ARBs are effective antihypertensive agents, they are not specifically required in defining resistant hypertension.

 

Option D. Vasodilator: Vasodilators can be considered in certain cases of hypertension but are not essential for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains uncontrolled despite the use of three antihypertensive medications, one of which must be a diuretic. Recognizing the importance of including a diuretic in the regimen is critical for effective blood pressure management and addressing the underlying causes of treatment resistance.

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis, including in pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of the normal bacterial flora.

 

  • Effectiveness: Metronidazole is highly effective against the anaerobic bacteria that are commonly implicated in bacterial vaginosis.
  • Safety: It is considered safe for use during pregnancy, making it the preferred treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for bacterial vaginosis and can be used if metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is not commonly used for bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly used for infections caused by gram-positive bacteria and atypical pathogens.

 

Option D. Rovamycin: Rovamycin (spiramycin) is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for the treatment of toxoplasmosis in pregnancy. It is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy due to its effectiveness against anaerobic bacteria and its safety profile during pregnancy.

 

Rovamycin i.e. spiramycin (which is a macrolide) is drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/894-896.

questions.text: The punishment for the death of a patient by spurious drug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Life imprisonment 

 

  • The punishment for the death of a patient by a spurious drug is life imprisonment as it leads to grievous hurt which is punishable by life imprisonment as per Drugs and Cosmetics act.
  • Spurious or imitation drug products are drug formulations manufactured. concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, the distribution of spurious drugs that result in death constitutes grievous hurt, warranting severe legal consequences including life imprisonment.

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Head injury

 

Cushing's ulcers are specifically associated with head injuries or conditions that lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The mechanism involves vagal nerve stimulation due to the increased ICP, which in turn causes an overproduction of gastric acid leading to the development of ulcers. This is distinct from other types of stress-related gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burns: This type of ulcer is known as Curling's ulcer, which occurs in response to severe burns and is related to the physiological stress and possible hypovolemia resulting from the burn injury, not the brain injury-related mechanism of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Option B. Stress: While stress can indeed lead to gastric ulcers, the specific term "Cushing's ulcers" is not used in this context. General stress-related ulcers do not typically involve the mechanism of vagal stimulation due to increased ICP.

 

Option D. Cell necrosis: This is a general process that can occur in many pathological conditions but does not specifically relate to the formation of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

questions.text: Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent congenitally in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic fibrosis

 

  • Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent, congenitally in cystic fibrosis. This is known as the congenital bilateral absence of vas deference (CBAVD) and is a causes of obstructive azoospermia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY) accounts or 1 to 2 percent of male infertility cases. Classically, these men are tall, undervirilized, and have gynecomastia and small, rm testes

 

Option C. Kallman syndrome: This is a form of congenital hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism with anosmia. It presents as primary amenorrhoea in women and with male infertility in men

 

Option D. Kartagener syndrome: Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens, leading to obstructive azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 229, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2P1

 

Explanation:

 

  • The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
    • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
    • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
    • L - Living children.
  • The GTPAL system includes the following:
    • Gravida
    • Term (>37 weeks)
    • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
    • Abortions (<20 weeks)
    • Number of living children

 

Obstetric Score

 

  • Gravidity:
    • G2 (Second pregnancy)
  • Parity:
    • P1 (One previous pregnancy reaching viability, twins count as one para)

 

So, the correct obstetric score for this lady is G2P1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gravida denotes the number of pregnancies, and para denotes the number of pregnancies reaching the period of viability. Twins count as one in the para score, and the current pregnancy is included in gravida but not in para until delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

It is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to gradually deteriorate, eventually leading to thyroid failure. It is most common in women between the ages of 45 and 65. The presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase causes it.

 

There is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with an intact capsule morphologically. It is clearly separated from the surrounding structures.

 

There are two types of Hashimoto's thyroiditis: the classic form, which is more common, and the fibrosing variant, which occurs in only 10% of cases.

 

The classic form is distinguished by diffuse, symmetric, firm, and rubbery thyroid enlargement. The fibrosing variant has a firm, enlarged thyroid with surrounding tissue compression.

 

Histologically:

 

  1. Classic form has intense lymphocytic infiltration, atrophied thyroid follicles, and follicular epithelial cells that have degenerated into Hurthle cells (also called Askanazy cells, or oxyphil cells, or oncocytes).
  2. The fibrosing variant of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by significant fibrous replacement of thyroid parenchyma and a less prominent lymphoid infiltrate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graves' disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, presence of anti-TSH receptor antibodies, and typically does not present with Hurthle cells.

 

  • Clinical features include exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and a diffusely enlarged hypervascular thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma: A type of thyroid cancer that presents with different histological features, such as follicular cell proliferation and capsular or vascular invasion, but not typically Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with amyloid deposits and elevated calcitonin levels.

 

  • Histologically different from Hashimoto's thyroiditis and does not feature Hurthle cells.

 

Educational Objective:
